title: How to Make Tomato Relish

steps.headline: Chop the tomatoes and onion into rough chunks.
Place them into a saucepan and add the remaining ingredients.
Leave to cook gently for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Keep checking on it regularly to gauge progress and to ensure that it isn't burning. Use a wooden spoon to stir now and then. If needed, thicken with 1 teaspoon of cornflour that has been mixed with water.

steps.headline: Once cooked, pour the relish straight into hot clean jars.
Prepare the ingredients:
steps.description: Remove the core and stem from the tomatoes. Chop roughly. Peel the onions, chop roughly. Remove the stem and seeds from the bell peppers. Chop roughly. Core the apples. Chop roughly. Leave the peel intact. Mince the garlic cloves.

steps.headline: Add the chopped ingredients to a heavy-based preserving pan or pot.
steps.description: Tip in the apple cider vinegar and the salt. Stir together.

steps.headline: Place the pot over high heat.
steps.description: Bring to the boil, then turn down to a simmer. Let simmer for 1 hour and 15 minutes. Stir now and then, checking that the mixture isn't burning on the base.

steps.headline: Chop the jalapeño peppers into small pieces.
steps.description: Remove the seeds from half of the peppers. Wear gloves to stop your hands from stinging.

steps.headline: Sterilize the jars to be used for the relish.
steps.description: All items used for canning must be sterilized too (lids, seals, tongs, spoons).

steps.headline: When the relish has boiled down, add the chopped jalapeño peppers, the fresh cilantro and the dried cumin.
steps.description: Mix through, then cook on a simmer for another 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Mash the relish with a potato masher. Boil again.

steps.headline: Transfer the hot relish into the hot sterilized jars.
steps.description: Seal and label. The seals must pop down; if not, that jar hasn't worked––transfer the ingredients back for more boiling or freeze the ingredients instead. (If still waiting for the lids to go down after the relish completely cools down, keep the relish in the refrigerator. After 12 hours, decide not to preserve the relish but instead consume it from the fridge within the next 2 weeks.) To freeze, place inside sterilized glass jars but allow room for expansion during freezing.

text: Tomato relish Chop the tomatoes and onion into rough chunks.  Place them into a saucepan and add the remaining ingredients. Bring to the boil gently. Leave to cook gently for 30 minutes. Keep checking on it regularly to gauge progress and to ensure that it isn't burning. Use a wooden spoon to stir now and then. If needed, thicken with 1 teaspoon of cornflour that has been mixed with water. Once cooked, pour the relish straight into hot clean jars. Cover with a sealing lid. Sugar-free tomato relish Prepare the ingredients: Remove the core and stem from the tomatoes. Chop roughly. Peel the onions, chop roughly. Remove the stem and seeds from the bell peppers. Chop roughly. Core the apples. Chop roughly. Leave the peel intact. Mince the garlic cloves. Add the chopped ingredients to a heavy-based preserving pan or pot. Tip in the apple cider vinegar and the salt. Stir together. Place the pot over high heat. Bring to the boil, then turn down to a simmer. Let simmer for 1 hour and 15 minutes. Stir now and then, checking that the mixture isn't burning on the base. Chop the jalapeño peppers into small pieces. Remove the seeds from half of the peppers. Wear gloves to stop your hands from stinging. Sterilize the jars to be used for the relish. All items used for canning must be sterilized too (lids, seals, tongs, spoons). When the relish has boiled down, add the chopped jalapeño peppers, the fresh cilantro and the dried cumin. Mix through, then cook on a simmer for another 5 minutes. Remove from the heat. Mash the relish with a potato masher. Boil again. Transfer the hot relish into the hot sterilized jars. Seal and label. The seals must pop down; if not, that jar hasn't worked––transfer the ingredients back for more boiling or freeze the ingredients instead. (If still waiting for the lids to go down after the relish completely cools down, keep the relish in the refrigerator. After 12 hours, decide not to preserve the relish but instead consume it from the fridge within the next 2 weeks.) To freeze, place inside sterilized glass jars but allow room for expansion during freezing. Finished.
